title: 111_hr1956
content: The Act is titled the "Crime Victim Restitution and Court Fee Intercept Act" and allows for the offset of state judicial debts against income tax refunds. The "Crime Victim Restitution and Court Fee Intercept Act" amends the Internal Revenue Code to allow for the collection of past-due, legally enforceable State judicial debts by reducing overpayments payable to individuals and paying the amount to the State judicial branch or agency. The Act allows for the collection of State judicial debts by reducing overpayments and paying the amount to the State judicial branch or agency. The offset notice includes names, taxpayer identification numbers, and addresses for joint returns. The Act allows for the collection of State judicial debts by reducing overpayments and paying the amount to the State judicial branch or agency. Overpayments are prioritized for reduction based on various liabilities, including internal revenue tax, past-due support, debts to Federal agencies, State income tax obligations, and covered unemployment compensation debt. The Act allows for the collection of State judicial debts by reducing overpayments and paying the amount to the State judicial branch or agency. Overpayments are prioritized for reduction based on various liabilities, including State income tax obligations and covered unemployment compensation debt. If multiple debts are owed to State agencies or judicial branches, overpayments will be applied in the order they accrued. Rules similar to subsection (e)(4) apply for debts under this subsection. The Act allows for the collection of State judicial debts by reducing overpayments and paying the amount to the State judicial branch or agency. Overpayments are prioritized for reduction based on various liabilities, including State income tax obligations and covered unemployment compensation debt. If multiple debts are owed to State agencies or judicial branches, overpayments will be applied in the order they accrued. Rules similar to subsection (e)(4) apply for debts under this subsection, including past-due, legally enforceable State judicial debts resulting from court judgments or sentences. The Secretary shall issue regulations prescribing the time and manner for State judicial branches and agencies to submit notices of past-due State judicial debts, including court costs, fees, fines, assessments, and restitution to victims of crime. Regulations will specify the necessary information to be included in such notices. The regulations will specify the types of State judicial monies and the minimum debt amount for reduction procedures. State branches and agencies may need to pay a fee to reimburse the Secretary for applying the procedure. Any erroneous payments made to State branches or agencies must be promptly returned to the Secretary according to regulations. The regulations specify types of State judicial monies and minimum debt amount for reduction procedures. Any erroneous payments made to State branches or agencies must be promptly returned to the Secretary according to regulations. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code regarding disclosure of return information and conforming amendments. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code regarding reduction procedures for State judicial debts. Section 6402 is amended to include subsections (g) and (f) for reduction and crediting of overpayments. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include provisions for reducing overpayments for State judicial debts and crediting future liabilities for Federal internal revenue tax. Effective date for refunds is after December 31, 2008.
